newsitem.title: UK: Wet Brent trades at Feb +20, unmoved by weakness.
newsitem.headline: Wet Brent trades at Feb +20, unmoved by weakness.

text.p: North Sea wet crudes remained well supported by demand during the afternoon on Friday despite weaker intermonth spreads and lower outright values.
A Jan 17-19 Brent traded at 20 cents over February, compared to Thursday's trade at +21 cents for a Jan 15-17 cargo.

Feb Brent was still trading about 25 to 30 cents a barrel below Thursday's close after API data released late on Thursday revealed a surprise build in U.S. crude stocks and a bigger than expected rise in distillate inventories.
European gas oil was also weighing on Brent with crack spread swaps under pressure.
Falling outright Brent values undermined CFDs and intermonth paper spreads, Feb/March slipping to +55/+58 cents from trade at +62 and +60 late on Thursday.
But wet North Sea crudes stayed firm after several January cargoes found homes with European refiners, traders said.
"There were quite a few deals done privately yesterday at higher numbers," said one. Another trader saw good demand and a strong chance of Oseberg or Urals trading on Friday.
A third decade Forties was heard sold for around Dated Brent +40/+42 cents on Thursday after a mid-month stem was offered for +35 cents. Details could not be immediately confirmed.
Four Brent cargoes, loading Jan 18-22, were due down the paper chains on Friday. It was unclear whether the holders of the two Jan 17-19 clocked cargoes had been granted deferrals.

In the Mediterranean, Urals talked a touch firmer helped by improved refinery margins but a prompt cargo was still offered by a trader at around Dated Brent -$1.10. "There are several cargoes around in both the north and south for the mid-decade (10-20 January)," said a trader.
Syria trimmed five cents off its offer for Jan Light crude but at Dated -30 cents it was still seen too high for most term customers. Syrian Light was fixed at Dated -5 cents in December.
